application.ref: A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

text.p: The absolute values presented here are also of similar order to the S1 last interglacial soil MAR reconstructed from OSL dates on the desert-marginal, north-eastern Chinese Loess Plateau site, Jingbian (150 g m^-2 a^-1 ; Buylaert et al., 2015).
The 100 year rates remain largely the same, with accretion decreasing by 0.1 mm yr-1 and OC burial decreasing by 7 kg/m^2/yr at Station 1 and 8 g/m^2/yr .

Although taken in close proximity, the two coreshave different mean Holocene sedimentation rates (GPC 5:19 cm kyr^-1; GGC 5: 9 cm kyr^-1), further illustrating the large variations in sediment accumulation rate that can exist within short distances on the seafloor. Not with standing the large difference in sedimentation rate, both cores give the same 230Th normalized fluxes (Figure 10). As predicted for this situation, the 230Th normalized fluxes of lithogenic material obtained on Bermuda Rise (16 g m^-2 year^-1) are much higher than the flux of lithogenic material originating from surface waters. The latter can be estimated from theflux of lithogenic material (2 g m-2year-1) measured witha sediment trap deployed at 3200 m (1300 m above theseafloor) at station OFP (32째050N, 64째150W;Conte et al.[2001]), and from the 230Th normalized flux of lithogenic material obtained from the Holocene section of a core fromthe same general area (CHN82 31 11PC; 42째230N,31째480W) but outside the drift deposit (1. 9 g m 2 year 1;Francois and Bacon[1994]).

Basin cores allowed us to calculate the sedimentation rates, respectively for glacial and interglacial intervals with an average sedimentation rate of 19.8 cm/yr. The mentioned rates are the highest documented for the Tyrrhenian Sea and among the highest registered for the central Mediterranean Sea with 14 cm/yr.
We have estimated an average sedimentation rate of 0.1 m/yr for the Tyrrhenian Sea. The mentioned rates are the highest documented with 0.2 m/yr.
At all we have a sedimentation rate of 17.5 cm/kyr, respectively with an avg sedimentation rate of 19.8 cm/kyr. Also we measured a sed of 10.7 m/kyr, also with a low barrier of 10.5 m/kyr.
